name: Nemed
shortDescription: Sacred space or sanctuary, a consecrated area set apart from the profane world
fullDescription: Nemed (Irish: sacred, privileged) refers to sacred space in Celtic tradition - areas consecrated and set apart from ordinary use. These include stone circles, sacred groves, springs, burial mounds, and ritual enclosures. A nemed is protected by spiritual power and often by legal prohibition; violating the sanctuary of a nemed brings supernatural punishment. The concept extends to sacred persons (druids, poets) and times (festivals) that share this quality of being set apart.

mythologyContexts.usage: Designation of sacred spaces where religious rituals occurred and which were protected from profanation. Druids performed ceremonies in nemed spaces. Violation of a nemed was a serious crime punishable by death or exile

textReferences.context: Legal protection for sacred spaces and persons designated as nemed
Descriptions of Celtic sacred groves and their inviolability

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents the threshold between sacred and profane, the center of spiritual power, and the axis mundi where heaven and earth meet. The circular or bounded nature of nemed spaces symbolizes completeness, protection, and the creation of order from chaos.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The concept of nemed shaped Irish land use and law for centuries. Certain locations retained sacred character even after Christianization. The term 'neimheadh' (modern Irish) still means 'sacred' or 'holy.' The legal protection of sacred spaces in Brehon law influenced medieval European concepts of sanctuary.

manifestations.description: Sacred groves where druids conducted rituals and taught students, protected from cutting or profanation
Stone circles and megalithic sites serving as ritual centers and astronomical observatories
Holy wells and springs, often associated with healing and pilgrimage

etymology.derivation: From Proto-Celtic *nemeton- (sacred grove, sanctuary) < Proto-Indo-European *nem- (to assign, to take). The nemed was both physical sacred space and legal status of sanctity

originPoint.name: Pan-Celtic (Ireland, Britain, Gaul)
originPoint.description: Nemed/nemeton concept universal across Celtic lands. Archaeological evidence: Drunemeton (Galatia), nemeton sites in Gaul, sacred groves in Britain, Irish legal nemed status. Place-name evidence widespread

firstAttestation.description: Archaeological evidence of nemeton sites and references in classical texts (Strabo, Lucan). Irish legal texts preserve nemed status system from pre-Christian period
